slide.title: Keyboard Support: Sequential Navigation and Cursor Keys

ul.li: Using the tab key to sequentially navigate to make sure all the links, form controls and any other interactive elements on the page can be accessed with the keyboard.
Pressing Space or Enter can activate a link, form control or other interactive elements.
Some interactive elememnts like menus, toolbars, spin buttons and sliders support cursor keys to move between items or change the value of the controls.
Menus can also support character keys to move between items that start with that character
Modal dialog boxes must constrain keyboard navigation to the controls in the dialog box.
Keyboard focus must always be on visible elements.
Bypass Blocks feature: Either a SkipTo link or "Skip To Main" link.

Default focus styling of links and form controls:
Vary between browsers.
Often disabled through "reset" stylesheets.

Best practices for focus styling:
Focus outline of at least 2 pixels in width.
At least 2 pixels of padding between outline the text of a link or borders of a form control.
Outline includes the label for checkboxes and radio buttons.
Outline meets WCAG color contrast requirements with background content.
GOAL: When looking at a web page for the first time it should be visually easy to identify the element with keyboard focus and to follow changes in focus.

contents.p: NOTE: When I test a website and keyboard focus is clearly vsiible and has been intergrated into the look and feel of the website, I am more confident other accessibility features have been addressed.

p.a: Test page for exploring the visual differences between passive and active focus styling.

ul.li: Video controls are not keyboard accessible.
Poor focus styling, relies on default focus styling with mixed results.
Keyboard activation for carousels operates on the second carousel and there is not sequential access to the carousel controls on the second carousel .
Poor focus styling, inconsistent used of active and default focus styling creates missing or ambivelent focus indication.
All links and controls can be accessed through the keyboard.
Keyboard activation and pointer "click" on items have same results.
Actively style keyboard focus to provide an outline around links and form controls.
Sub-menu open/close controls not easy to discerne.
If search opened, it is not automatically closed and obscures content.
Generally good keyboard focus styling with use of a outline.
Some keyboard enhancements result in lost focus, using arrow keys when a menu is open.
Poor keyboard focus, relies mostly on color changes and no outlining.

Move your mouse away from your work station or cover your track pad to allow your attention to be only on using the keyboard. Note: Recommend using Firefox since it's default focus styling is less apparent than Chrome or Safari.
Use the tab key to navigate to links, form controls and other interactive content on the page.

Questions to ask your self:
Can I tell where keyboard focus is on the page?
Can I activate controls using the Space or Enter keys? DO they perform the same action?
Does the navigation of controls seem predictable.
Does focus ever disappear and then magically reapear? If you answer yes, this means there is content being obscured and this is not good for accessibility. Only visible elements should have focus.
Can I use the cursor keys to navigate or change the state of some types of interactive elements.
